Executive Summary ? Salt Creek Gas Plant  (2009)

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

The Salt Creek Gas Plant operations center has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training our personnel as well as the safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our processes.  Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of potentially hazardous or regulated substances.  However, if a release would occur, the Emergency Action Plan (EAP) will be initiated and trained gas plant operators would respond to control and contain the release.

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE(S) AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Salt Creek Gas Plant, located outside of Midwest, Wyoming, USA, operates a variety of processes to extract light hydrocarbons from the natural gas stream from the Salt Creek oil field.  These light hydrocarbons include methane, ethane, propane, butane and pentanes.  The propane, butanes and pentanes are sold as a Y-grade mixture to other facilities for further separation.  The methane and ethane is sold or consumed on site or in the nearby field for fuel.  The Salt Creek gas plant uses one regulated flammable material in it?s process, that being propane which is used as a refrigerant to cool the natural gas stream to recover the liquids.  The natural gas stream which feeds the plant contains a small amount of Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S), which is also regulated; however the entire amount of H2S in the plant is less than the threshold quantity.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The following is a summary of the accident prevention program in place at the Salt Creek Gas Plant.  The processes are regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency?s (EPA?s) Risk

Management Program (RMP) and the Occupation Safety and Health Administration?s (OSHA?s) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.  The following summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program.

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

The management of the Salt Creek Gas Plant requires employees to participate in all facets of PSM and accident prevention.  Examples of this include: updating and compiling documents to fulfill the Process Safety Information concerning the nature of the chemicals used at the facility and the design and operation of the equipment; the use of a Management of Change process to alter any equipment, chemicals, or procedures used at the facility; participation as members of a Process Hazards Analysis team; writing of and verification of procedures used at the facility as well as active participation in the emergency response training.  Employees have full access to all information created as part of the PSM and accident prevention programs.  

PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION

The Salt Creek Gas Plant maintains a collection of technical documents that are used to continue the safe operation of the processes.  These documents address the chemical properties and associated hazards, operational limits for key process parameters and consequences of deviation, equipment design basis and configuration information, electrical classifications within the plant  as well as the process flow drawings and plant layout diagrams.  Specific individuals within the plant are assigned the responsibility of maintaining this information to assure that the information is current with present conditions.

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations is provided in the Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) for all chemicals stored or used on site.  For specific process areas, the safety-related information including all design and

operational limits on the equipment is maintained on Pipe & Instrument Diagrams (P&ID) along with the normal operating conditions.  The gas plant ensures that the process is maintained within these limits using process controls, monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel and protective instrument systems such as automatic shutdowns.  

The plant also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of the process equipment.  This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment.  This information, along with process operating parameters is used to develop written procedures that are used to establish inspection and maintenance activities.  Additionally, the procedures are used to train operators and assure that the safety features in the process are not compromised.

PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS (PHA)

The company has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each process is systematically studied to identify hazards and that appropriate controls are in place to manage those hazards.

The company has used the ?what if? method along with a corporate method referred to as the DP-10 method of conducting the PHA.  These analyses are conducted using a team of individuals who have the operating and maintenance experience as well as the engineering expertise to evaluate the systems in the process.  The team is tasked with identifying and evaluating hazards within the process as well as identifying accident prevention and mitigation measures.  Using this information, the team suggests additional prevention and/or mitigation measures if the team believes such measures are necessary.  Based on a hazard ranking system, the findings are forwarded to the plant engineer and local management for resolution.  If they can not be resolved at a local level, the r

ecommendations are forwarded to corporate management until the recommendation can be resolved.  The hazard ranking method is to assure those items with the highest priority are resolved in as quickly as possible.  All responses and resolutions are documented and tracked until completed or signed off by a responsible party.  The final resolution to all findings are documented and kept with the PHA for the life of the facility.

To ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety features, the plant reviews, updates and revalidates the PHA.  These reviews are held at least every five years and will continue to be conducted at this interval until the plant is no longer operating.  The results and findings from these updates and reviews are documented and retained with the original PHA.  If there are findings or recommendations found during this review process, they are forwarded to management for consideration.  The final resolution of the findings are documented and retained.

OPERATING PROCEDURES

The Salt Creek Gas Plant maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations such as: 1) unit startup; 2) normal operations; 3) emergency shutdown; 4) normal shutdown; 5) initial startup of a new process and others.  These procedures are used for reference by the experienced operators and provide a basis for the consistent training of new operators.  Each procedure is reviewed and certified annually to assure it reflects the operating conditions and operations of the facility.  These are kept current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes in the process or operational conditions.  The changes are documented using the Management of Change process. 

In addition, the procedures at the Salt Creek Gas Plant include a section that provides guidance on how to respond to exceedances from specific process parameters such as high/low temperatures or pressur

es.  This information is imbedded in the written procedures so operators and others have access to it at all times.  

TRAINING

To complement the written process operating procedures, the Salt Creek Gas Plant has a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process.  New employees receive basic training in gas plant operations. After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks.  After operators demonstrate having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently.  In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level.  This refresher training is conducted at least every three years and more frequently if there are changes to procedures or processes.  All training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify the operators understanding of the training.

CONTRACTORS
 
The Salt Creek Gas Plant uses contractors to supplement its work force during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the gas plant has procedures in place to ensure that contractors; 1) perform their work in a safe manner, 2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, 3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, 4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, 5) understand and follow site safety rules, and 6) inform gas plant personnel of any hazards that they find during their work.  This is accomplished by providing contractors with; 1) process overview, 2) information about safety and health hazards, 3) emergency response plan requirements, 4) safe work practices prior to their beginning work, and 5) safe and hot work permits as required.  In addition the Salt Creek Gas Plant evaluates

contractor safety programs and performance during the selection of a contractor using our company Contractor Assessment Program as well as onsite observations.

PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEWS (PSSRs)

The Salt Creek Gas Plant conducts a PSSR for any change in the process or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information.  The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.  This review provides one additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready.  The PSSR review team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness.  A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves as a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

The Salt Creek Gas Plant has well established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps, heat exchangers, compressors and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.  The basic aspects of this program include; 1) conducting training, 2) developing written procedures, 3) performing inspections and tests, 4) correcting identified deficiencies, and 5) applying quality assurance measures.  In combination these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process. 

Maintenance personnel receive training on; 1) an overview of the process, 2) safety and health hazards 3) applicable maintenance procedures, 4) emergency response plans, and 5) applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their jobs in a safe manner.  Written procedures help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training.  Inspections and tests are performed t

o verify that equipment parameters are within acceptable limits.  If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service (if possible) or a management of change team will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment.  

SAFE WORK PRACTICES
 
The Salt Creek Gas Plant has long standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  Examples of these include; 1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, 2) a lockout/tagout program to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, 3) procedures for safe removal of hazardous substances before process piping or equipment is opened, 4) a permit and procedure to control spark producing activities (i.e. hot work), and 5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space.  These procedures along with training of affected personnel form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

The Salt Creek Gas Plant has a comprehensive system to manage changes to all covered processes. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology, procedures and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to; 1) ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards, 2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change, and 3) ensure that changes do not introduce an unknown hazard to the process.  Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits and equipment information, as well as procedures are updated to incorporate these changes.  In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided necessary training on the change.

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

The Salt Creek Gas Plant p

romptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in a fire/explosion, major property damage, environmental loss or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The investigation team documents it findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence and forwards these results to gas plant management for resolution.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented and the investigation results reviewed with all employees and affected contractors who could be affected by the findings.  Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations.

COMPLIANCE AUDITS 

To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the Salt Creek Gas Plant periodically conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented.  Compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years.  Both hourly and staff personnel participate as audit team members.  The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to gas plant management for resolution.  Corrective actions that result in response to the audit team?s findings are tracked until they are completed.  The final resolution of each finding and corrective action are documented and the two most recent audits are retained.

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The processes at the Salt Creek Gas Plant have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation.  The following is a description of existing safety features applicable to prevention of accidental releases of regulates substances in the facility.

GENERAL PREVENTION ACTIVITIES  

The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all RMP covered processes at the Salt Creek Gas Plant.  Col

lectively these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failure and human errors.

SPECIALIZED SAFETY FEATURES
 
The Salt Creek Gas Plant has safety features on many units to help; 1) contain/control a release 2) quickly detect a release, and 3) reduce the consequence of a release.  The following types of safety features are used in the covered processes:

Release Detection
?  Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms
?  H2S detectors with alarms
?  Fire detectors tied into automated facility shutdowns

Release Containment/Control
?  Process relief valves that either discharge to a safe area or discharge to a flare system that captures and incinerates any episodic releases
?  Manual and automated valves to isolate portions or all of the process
?  Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high stack temperatures, high/low pressures, etc..) 
?  Redundant equipment and instrumentation where feasible

Release Mitigation
?  Fire extinguishers located throughout the plant
?  Operators trained in emergency response and process control
?  Personal Protective Equipment including chemical protective clothing, Self-Contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA) and supplied air respirators


FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Salt Creek Gas Plant has an excellent record of accident prevention over the past five years.  During that time, there have not been any incidents that did or could have resulted in an hydrocarbon releases whose quantities approached those described in the RMP release events.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

The Salt Creek Gas Plant maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect worker and public safety and the environment.  The program consists of procedure for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address all aspects of e

mergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post incident cleanup.  In addition the plant has procedures that address maintenance, inspection and testing of emergency equipment.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to the plant.  The emergency response program changes are administered through the MOC process, which includes informing and/or training affected personnel in the changes.

The overall emergency response program of the Salt Creek Gas Plant is coordinate with the Midwest Fire Department and the Natrona County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  This coordination includes periodic meeting of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials and industry representatives.  The Salt Creek Gas Plant has around the clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations.  This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to emergency situations.  In addition to periodic meetings with the LEPC, the Salt Creek Gas Plant conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the local emergency response organizations.  Annual refresher training is available to local emergency responder regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the gas plant.   

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Salt Creek Gas Plant resolves all findings form PHAs and audits, some of which have resulted in modifications to the process.  These modifications are typically completed during scheduled turnarounds at the facility.  Some examples of these are:
?  Re0activated second de-meth

anized NGL storage tank
?  Installed Inlet gas compressor (Knight)
?  Replaced 1st stage coalescing filter with a scrubber
?  Installed new process chiller

Additional changes are planned over the next few years in response to PHA, Environmental and Safety Audits, and general plant improvements:
?  De-bottleneck the plant to increase capacity and throughput
?  Explore options to increase the amine sweetening section of the plant to facilitate better CO2 and H2S removal from the inlet gas stream
